pageProps.contentHtml:
mean value property

Let F\mathcal{F}F be the family of functions fff holomorphic on D\DD with

∬{x2+y2<1}∣f(x+iy)∣2 dx dy<1.\iint_{\set{x^2 + y^2 < 1}} \abs{f\p{x + iy}}^2 \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} < 1.∬{x2+y2<1}​∣f(x+iy)∣2dxdy<1.

Prove that for each compact subset K⊆DK \subseteq \DK⊆D there is a constant AAA so that ∣f(z)∣<A\abs{f\p{z}} < A∣f(z)∣<A for all z∈Kz \in Kz∈K and all f∈Ff \in \mathcal{F}f∈F.
Solution.

First, let B(z0,R)B\p{z_0, R}B(z0​,R) be an open ball with closure contained in D\DD. Let f∈Ff \in \mathcal{F}f∈F, so that we can apply the mean value property:

f(z0)=12π∫02πf(z0+Reiθ) dθ.f\p{z_0} = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f\p{z_0 + Re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta.f(z0​)=2π1​∫02π​f(z0​+Reiθ)dθ.

Multiplying by 2r2r2r, integrating from 000 to RRR, and applying a change-of-coordinates, we end up with the two-dimensional mean value property:

f(z0)=1πR2∫B(z0,R)f(x+iy) dA.f\p{z_0} = \frac{1}{\pi R^2} \int_{B\p{z_0,R}} f\p{x + iy} \,\diff{A}.f(z0​)=πR21​∫B(z0​,R)​f(x+iy)dA.

By the triangle inequality, Hölder's inequality, and assumption on F\mathcal{F}F,

∣f(z0)∣≤1πR2∫B(z0,R)∣f(x+iy)∣ dA≤1πR2(∫B(z0,R)∣f(x+iy)∣2 dA)1/2(∫B(z0,R)dA)1/2≤m(B(z0,R))1/2πR2≤m(D)1/2πR2.\begin{aligned} \abs{f\p{z_0}} &\leq \frac{1}{\pi R^2} \int_{B\p{z_0,R}} \abs{f\p{x + iy}} \,\diff{A} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{\pi R^2} \p{\int_{B\p{z_0,R}} \abs{f\p{x + iy}}^2 \,\diff{A}}^{1/2} \p{\int_{B\p{z_0,R}} \diff{A}}^{1/2} \\ &\leq \frac{m\p{B\p{z_0, R}}^{1/2}}{\pi R^2} \\ &\leq \frac{m\p{\D}^{1/2}}{\pi R^2}. \end{aligned}∣f(z0​)∣​≤πR21​∫B(z0​,R)​∣f(x+iy)∣dA≤πR21​(∫B(z0​,R)​∣f(x+iy)∣2dA)1/2(∫B(z0​,R)​dA)1/2≤πR2m(B(z0​,R))1/2​≤πR2m(D)1/2​.​

where mmm denotes the Lebesgue measure. Now let K⊆DK \subseteq \DK⊆D be any compact set, and let δ=12d(K,Dc)\delta = \frac{1}{2}d\p{K, \D^\comp}δ=21​d(K,Dc), which is positive since it's a distance between two disjoint closed sets. For any z∈Kz \in Kz∈K, B(z,δ)⊆DB\p{z, \delta} \subseteq \DB(z,δ)⊆D, so by our previous calculation,

∣f(z)∣≤m(D)1/2πδ2\abs{f\p{z}} \leq \frac{m\p{\D}^{1/2}}{\pi\delta^2}∣f(z)∣≤πδ2m(D)1/2​

for all z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D. This bound is independent of choice of fff, so this bound holds for all f∈Ff \in \mathcal{F}f∈F as well, which completes the proof.
